ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: (On Question 1) I think the course is structured well and the topics covered are important for students focusing on coastal issues. I struggled a bit with some of the readings, which occasionally didn't feel especially related to the discussions we had in class. We were also assigned a lot of reading, which was manageable, but it sometimes seemed like there wasn't a clear connection between some of the readings and the general "topic" for the day.

I thought there were way too many readings assigned for each class meeting. Also, many of the readings were relatively unnecessary for the conceptual goals of the course. I also think it would've been nice to have more guidance and how we were to lead the course on days where we were assigned to do so. Finally, I feel that despite the Ghana project be an interesting exercise, we probably could have done an even better job or we given a folder of resources to examine ourselves. Not just literature on Ghana but the many examples of CRC literature that we found relatively late in the process of writing our proposals and appendices.
The professor was great but I believe there were too many readings. Also it will be helpful in the future if the class discussions were shreter with more discussion lead by te professor

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The array of articles discussing contemporary issues and the class discussions
Great discussions, insight into policy process, small class group work

I really enjoyed the discussions we had in class debating various policy approaches to problems in coastal management. Those were especially useful to me because I got to hear a lot of viewpoints from other students with diverse backgrounds/experience.

I just think the best part about this course is that we get to focus in on policy related to just water in coastal spaces. This is incredibly valuable in that it avoids the need to study lots of other things as well. That said, I feel the way in which we focused in on certain policies or not wasn't really made clear, and I'm not sure that the readings we had for each class oppose the right questions and analysis of these policies.
It provides an overall view of coastal governance systems and the professor is very experienced so learning from his experiences was very valuable

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Perhaps less readings per person for the purposes of presentation.

Reading load each week is extremely heavy, often making it difficult to complete all of them. Would recommend paring down the readings to only the most significant or dividing readings into necessary and recommended.

I think the class itself needs a little clearer structure in terms of the readings and what students are expected to bring to the table at each class meeting. I was sometimes frustrated that we were assigned a lot of reading, and some of the readings didn't seem to necessarily pertain that much to the overall policy discussions in class. I think the class could be improved by selecting readings that may provide a little more "bang-for-buck" so that students can complete the readings closely and come to class with substantive comments for discussion, rather than trying to complete a large amount of reading that touches on many different and only somewhat interrelated topics.

Weekly class meetings: too many readings, not enough information on what to focus on... Often didn't feel like we were getting to where we're supposed to in class ends up being more circular discussion. This can be kind of frustrating a policy class. Ghana project: not really enough guidance or help with research to improve our final product
Less readings. Final project should be decided individually depending on students interests

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No course lectures no discussion/lab section
There were too many readings to really capture them all in one week, and for the final project there were more readings that could be useful besides the ones recommended

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Very interested in continuing to work in this field so this class was greatly aligned with my current and future work.
Course works well with other intro policy and science classes.
I was hoping to use this class to supplement my understanding of water quality issues and coastal problems, trying to get a pure policy perspective.

I really like taking a governance course, specially ecause there aren't many in FES but still I felt like it could be a little more international orienteted and Maybe looking into some practical skills of how to involve stakeholders and evaluate and monitor projects would be greAt

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: TO be exposed to more material on the topic and to learn more about the coastal policy process.
There are very few coast-focused courses at FES and this represents an important one.
I took coastal ecosystems last semester, and I thought this class would be a good policy analog to learn about governance structures affecting coastlines.
I took this course because I wanted to learn about coastal/water policy but I didn't want to spend a whole semester learning about general theoretical policy applied to environmental issues.
Recommended by other faculty

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes

They didn't necessarily meet my expectations but that is because my expectations kind of changed during the course. I didn't expect the course to ask me to work as part of a team on a climate finance proposal, so that was a new experience for me and definitely gave me some important knowledge. I think generally I derived a lot of useful knowledge from this course that I will find valuable in my career.

I think I learned a lot in this course but I wish I had more exposure to some of the takeaways. I think it would've been helpful to have more guidance throughout the course and how best to approach each of the class sessions and the goals intended in the study of those topics.

In the theory aspects yes, but I think the final project was not so helpful for me to understand everything learned in class. I would have preferred to do a project in the governance system of my country

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We got to share our experiences and learn from each other

Advantages included drawing on knowledge from students with different areas of expertise and experience, and having individuals you could count on to provide feedback on your own contributions throughout the course of the project. Disadvantages included a general struggle with the directions that we had and the deliverables we were expected to produce, and the usual scheduling conflicts that inevitably crop up when students are working outside of class as part of a team.

I liked working in a group for this project because it really made sense to split up the analyses. However, I feel that the final product of our efforts didn't completely reflect the work many of us put in. We had a limited amount of time and I think this and document creation could have benefited from more time. But we had little time available to spend on it by the time we were supposed to turn it in. I think by the end of the semester people were overwhelmed.
My group was really good and I really enjoyed working with them

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Working together as a class on readings and studying was hugely beneficial.

Ask a lot of questions so that you can get a clearer sense of what is expected. The readings can be broad, so it's important that you work to derive your own lessons/themes from them and determine how those themes pertain to the general topic for discussion.

Just know what you're getting into. The professor of this course is super knowledgeable in coastal policy, but the course at least this year was very free-form without a lot of guidance. So just think if you're the type of person that likes or doesn't like this style of course. If the Ghana climate finance project continues I think this is a valuable exercise, but needs more work from the professors and providing guidance and support throughout the project.
Ask about the final Project and see if it fits your intetrst
